title: Is software testing a good career choice? - Quora

response.answer_text: Well, There is nothing wrong to start the career with software testing. But let me assume some things.( assuming only because , as you now I was also fresher and have fear of same :-) May not suit to you.). a) being a fresher out from the collage , where you have been taught about how you can develop software or system and mange the system. b) having high enthusiasm for developing as friends also show casing the small things they developed with fun. There are other things and scenarios as well. Let’s consider one scenario that will help to remove some fear to take up software testing. Let’s say, your developing the bigger system , to understand easily, consider quora. :-) You wanted to develop the quora platform , and you started writing the code as developer.( as developer only Thinks about requirement fulfillment with accurate as possible). Now let’s say there is no software testing person or team in this picture, just couple of peoples who had idea and wrote the code and made it live. Now though they are very good coders, There will be some glitches, as when traffic gets high , information get collected, server gets loaded, and site got crashed. Issue comes to team, when they debug the issue they found some glitches in the database memory allotment, even holes in network section from where the hacker can easily take information. This issue comes in picture and media, and the reputation is went down by night. though superb launch, because of glitches it went down also the reputation they build is also gone. NOW in this scenario, take the software testing people in. Now this peoples job is to find bugs as many as possible , and test beyond levels to ensure in real world scenario it would not FAIL. As software testing people have to have some development skills to perform automation or manual, black box or white box testing., with the mind sharp to find needles in haystacks. :-)/ So, It’s nothing wrong in it., And every company needs software testing people because, before sending to real world they want to test. and a developer will not able to test from all angle. So , yes it’s good to start your career from software testing :-). Hope this helps, Thanks

That depends on the following criteria: You enjoy not ever having enough time or people to test anything correctly or effectively You bathe in the joy of always being under pressure to catch every single bug You look forward to getting blamed for everything that goes wrong, even before it goes wrong (the terms pre-blaming and blamestorming came from software testing) Relish in being treated like a second class citizen in the development world Walk the halls knowing everyone thinks they can do a better testing job Hearing whispers that monkeys can do a better testing job Accepting that monkeys are insulted by software testers Vague requirements and user stories is an opportunity for understanding You thrill in the love of chasing answers to questions, only to have more questions by the time they get answered Appreciate that your management never has confidence in you, but will most certainly take credit when you perform like a rock star Okay with rock stars see software testers as annoying You love the opportunity to try to explain in 12 seconds why a 5 minute code change takes 3 hours of testing before being interrupted to ‘Just get it done as fast as you can. Tonight.’ You love explaining, for the 5th time, why doubling the testers will not take half the time to get it done to the same management team that started the project 2 weeks ago. You can master the ‘bewildered face’ when asked why you missed testing something that was never in the testing scope. You can then master the ‘Of course it’s my fault’ when admonished for not mentioning ever in any meeting why it was not part of the testing scope. Disciplined in carefully explaining why automation testing does not substitute good manual testing…to the same people repeatedly over the course of several months, possibly years. Mastered how to find your happy place when a project manager asks, “You can do performance testing. Just take a recorded script and play it a thousand times, right?” Look forward to giving your best ‘I understand’ look when a programme manager says, “We have concerns with your testing approach” before the project planning even kicks off. You can appreciate the idea that testing has to explain in excruciating details everything they do, but development doesn’t have to say a word. Every. Single. Day. Possibly weekends. Maybe in your sleep. In the dark. In the cold. When everyone else is making money acting silly on reality television. You’ve clearly crossed Reality Television Celebrity off your career list. Other than that? It is a fantastic career. I’ve enjoyed it quite a bit :)

It is not a good career choice if you think software testing is just an another job. But it is one of the best career when you think you are like a detective! Especially a detective who cares about his victim and get on to find the defects. As a career,QA or QE leads to Test Manager or something like Test Automation Architect over a period of time. But it is one of the niche field if you choose to learn new everyday. For example, I learnt tools such as TestModelerIO and Mutation Testing as of today Similarly you need to be strong in some specialised testing such as web accessibility testing in this competitive world. So you get a high paid job as well as job security! In my case, I learnt accessibility with extra care since it was taught by someone who dont have 79% vision. Yes-you read it right. He dont have 79% human vision. When he taught me how to test websites to match necessary accessibility standards, I found it more of manual testing and manual testing only! Later understood that manual testing remain strong through these type of special testing. Why am I so much (worried and) care about this accessibility testing? See this image:  Please can you pretend to be this man for one hour and access computer? Kindly give a try. You will know how hard their life as a differently abled user on any websites. How about thinking about this talented chap accessing computer?  Even it was told to me that there are people use their nose or tongue to access computers (not joking here):  If you think I am talking about very less number of people here, it is completely wrong. 16.5% world population is disabled in one or the other kind. It is the actual reality. Reference: WHR We use websites for temperature-check to tickets-booking and almost majority of the work has been made online these days but very few websites are accessibility friendly(painful truth). When users with disability don’t have access to mouse and try accessing keyboard (only) to navigate in sites, do you know how hard it is become? I have written detailed examples on how it affects any user when they need accessibility at: Advanced Selenium Web Accessibility Testing: Software Automation Testing Secrets Revealed, Narayanan Palani, eBook - Amazon.com Mainly I have given this course as a UDEMY training to entire world in which 113 country based participants(2K+) are joined free this month to learn web accessibility:  It was become a new sensation in social media soon after releasing the course and it overtook the previous web accessibility course by 2341 enrolments in the first 24 days of release: Web Accessibility Testing - Selenium,BDD,Axe,Pa11y,JAWS,NVDA Now I am trying to reach more people to tell the secret that this type of accessibility testing jobs are highly paid! Example:  90+ jobs found in Monster UK website itself!  When you test for these special users to make their life easy,please tell me-is it not an interesting career like a doctor,scientist and police?

Thanks for A2A. There are so many ‘aye’ answers. And they are not wrong. My answer is also yes. But, let me add some riders. #1. If you are a tester for a public facing software (like Banking, telecom), yes, it is a good choice. But, if the software that you are testing is for internal use of a company, make sure of an evaluation first. #2. If you are a tester for software being developed in a vendor’s place, even for a public facing software, make sure of an evaluation. (This is with the logic that the company putting the software in public use will have more rigorous testing in place and some ‘leeway’ may be feasible for the vendor tester. Also the Vendor may not have a full appreciation and the responsibility for the ultimate status) #3. Ask the hypothetical question: if the testing team demands that the software should not be released, will the Management listen? (Agreed - you may not be in a hierarchy to find the answer - but you can look at the trend). If the answer is that you are likely to get Management’s instruction to make compromises, make sure of an evaluation (towards your question) first. #4. Review the project plan - are you sure that there is enough time allotted for testing in the Project Plan? If not, make sure of an evaluation first. #5. During appraisal, does a similar increment percentage / quantum applies to #5. If you are in software testing team where the testing / QA is provided more for ISO purposes, you are in trouble. Though life may be easier right now, you will see later on that you have started slipping in the career. Assuming that you find that the above points have been evaluated and you are happy about them, go into testing. But graduate beyond ‘following instructions’ for testing. Get an overall idea about the system. Apart from the project manager (rather the mentor or the architect) of the project, only two people will have a very good knowledge about the system: documentation person and the testing person. Become an indispensable knowledge repository. Your value will be increased.

I have over 8 years of experience in Software Testing Implementation, Training etc. While writing this answer it makes me reminisce all I have done. Lets start assuming Software Testing is not a good job.  As a Test Engineer or probably a QA engineer you would: Learn what the 'software' does?Learn what the 'client' needs?Identify the gapRinse and RepeatThis sounds simple isn't it? Yes, it is. We don't do simple things for long enough. Life gets monotonous and boring. But you can see I have stuck to this for 8 long years, indeed it has got something more than being simple.   Everyday, you learn new things and implement in improvising either: The product/service that you testYour technique of testingNow, lets talk about pay scale.  I am a trainer, consultant and practitioner in various test technologies and types. Since the beginning of my experience I have been paid at par with other engineering roles.  Talk about training or consulting, charges are steep here too. Now, lets understand Job Satisfaction: You are responsible for the deliverable qualityYou liaise directly with the client or end userYou work with the developers If you are filled with curiosity and a driving passion to learn I am sure you would be always satisfied. Also, remember that today, the world is customer driven. Until softwares are developed, testing will be done. Now going back wards, software testing is a job that is simple, easy to learn, pays off well, ever growing and is challenging enough to keep you motivated should be considered as a ____ job. (good/bad) Hope you can decide yourself and fill in the blanks above. Thank you.

Well there are common myths in the market about software testing as a career choice like:- Myth I . Software Testing as a Career pays Less.Developers are more respected as compared to Testers Reality:- Contrary to popular belief, Software Testers (better known as QA professionals) are paid and treated at par with Software Developers in all "aspiring" companies. A career in Software Testing should never be considered as "second rated." Myth II. Software Testing is Boring Reality:- Software Testing could actually "test" your nerves since you need to make sense of Business Requirements and draft test cases based on your understanding. Software testing is not boring. What is boring is doing the same set of tasks repeatedly. The key is to try new things. For that matter, have you ever spoken to a software developer with more than 3 years' experience? He will tell you how boring his job has become off-lately. There are alternate career tracks for a Software Tester Once you have got yours hand dirty in manual testing, you can pursue following specializations Automation Testing: As an Automation Test Engineer, you will be responsible for automating manual test case execution which otherwise could be time-consuming. Tools used are IBM Rational Robot, Silk performer, Selenium and QTP. Performance Testing: As a performance test engineer, you will be responsible for checking application responsiveness (time is taken to load, maximum load application can handle), etc. Tools used are WEBLoad, Jmeter, Loadrunner. Business Analyst: A major advantages Testers have over Developers is that they have an end to end business knowledge. An obvious career progression for testers is to become a Business Analyst. As a Business Analyst, you will be responsible to analyze and assess your company's business model and workflows, and especially how they integrate with technology. Based on your observation you will suggest and drive process improvements. Your career progression as a software tester (QA Analyst) will look like following but will vary from company to company:- Software tester (QA Analyst)(Fresher) => Sr. QA Analyst => QA Team Coordinator => Test Manager=> Senior Test Manager . You are a QA either by choice or by chance, known for your quality of bug or for quantity of bugs, emphasizing on manual testing or automation testing, you are playing an important role. The ultimate purpose of software testing is not to find bugs only but to make the product qualitative. As a tester, you are contributing in improvements of the product quality. Knowingly or unknowingly, you are trying to make the world better and that is a big responsibility. All the best

It’s a career by chance not by choice, I had been worked with QA team over the last 4 years, and I’m telling you it’s kind of testing devops shit, initially there will be a lot of bugs so you will be busy tracking bugs and making documents gradually you’re work will reduce as the number of bugs will be less by beta version of application. if there’s no bugs there’s no job for you, so do pray for more bugs and keep the developer busy all the time. Good coders can fix the bugs in no time if it’s not a major one, bad coders will ruin your day. Majority of the time I used to test manually but at the end of the day its not going to give you good experience, but for sure you’ll have end - to - end business domain idea once you completely test the application. My suggestion- It’s not a bad career but majority of people ended up being a tester as they were not interested in coding or basically they didn’t get the basic idea ( algorithms’ data structures .. languages etc). Though you initially testing every component manually, at some point when application is stable especially where there’s no much bugs/issues you should try automation ( Ask developers to give you a chance for blackbox testing/unit testing/load testing and so on) definitely that’ll give you a strong base in testing. TESTING BY CHANCE NOT BY CHOICE, WORK HARD AND FIND A WAY TO GET INTO DEVELOPMENT SIDE. ALL THE BEST

Good coders can fix the bugs in no time if it’s not a major one, bad coders will ruin your day. Majority of the time I used to test manually but at the end of the day its not going to give you good experience, but for sure you’ll have end - to - end business domain idea once you completely test the application. My suggestion- It’s not a bad career but majority of people ended up being a tester as they were not interested in coding or basically they didn’t get the basic idea ( algorithms’ data structures .. languages etc). All the best.

There are two ways to look at this. The ideal way says that a software developer should not limit themselves to certain strata and do horizontal splitting of responsiblities. (i.e., into back-end devs, front-end devs, testers, Dev-Ops etc), but rather do vertical splits (where each person learns and does a portion of the whole vertical (right from front-end work to Dev-Ops). Of course, each person has a certain strong area where they are good at, but they also get out of their comfort-zone every now and then and do the other parts. The pragmatic way (which is followed by the majority) lets an engineer pick an area where they are good at and work on only that, while communicating with the people in the other areas to stitch the product together. My observation: Although the ideal way is (as it implies) the best solution, the constraints to achieving it are talent, hard work and time. More specifically:1. Even to achieve a certain degree of mastery and comfort in one strata is quite difficult and takes time.2. Each strata is also continuously evolving and the Dev must spend some time and effort on evolving with the latest trends.3. Hence, to maintain a certain level of mastery in more than one strata is difficult indeed. While it is easy for me to learn more than one strata, it is partly because of my intelligence, education, experience working with a certain level of Developers that has given me this ability. There are those who are more capable Engineers than me and those that less so. Identifying my own strengths and weaknesses are therefore more important than fulfilling some idealistic standards set by someone else. In summary: If you feel that testing is something you feel comfortable with and feel happy about it, don’t let others ideals dissuade you. However, do also remember that if at any point you realize you have mastered testing and want a challenge, try mastering the other stratas.

Let’s admit, a 10-year-old kid won’t tell you his dream is to grow up and make a career as a software tester. It is usually a choice of an adult person, but there is always a question: how does one start? Today we are talking about the benefits of being an engineer in such a peculiar IT field and how to become a QA Tester. QA Testers are in a great demand these days because 500-600 websites are created every minute. The number of software, digital products, games, and web-platforms is insane, and they all need to be thoroughly checked before release. Hence, many young people wonder how to become a video game tester or a product tester, and what the general QA tester requirements are. Software testers have extensive and very flexible career paths that they may change according to their needs. They can become Project Managers if they have a good understanding of the numerous industries. QA Testers sometimes become DevOps because of their working approach. While developers have an in-depth, detailed way of thinking, testing engineers see the product as a whole, integral object. Therefore, they are able to rule the development process on the higher levels. A User Experience designer is also a profession that may be acquired by more creative QAs. They test products not only in terms of bugs and errors but also in terms of appearance. The list of possibilities can be extended even more, yet the main career path that QA may pave — is a QA engineer. Strategic thinking, business-oriented approach, and solid knowledge of testing tools and techniques are the major factors for building a successful career. Nowadays QAs can prove their skills by passing the test of ISTQB and receiving the according software tester certification.

Software has become more powerful and in the process, it has also become extremely complex. Testing, then, is also not simple and requires expensive, sophisticated tools, proper infrastructure and highly skilled technical team that works hand in hand with the developers who constructed/coded the software. From career perspective, Software Quality Assurance (SQA) as it is sometimes called is likely to be an integral part of any professional software development life cycle (SDLC). However, due to sensitive nature of defects that are found during this testing, (and also due to complex nature of related team discussions), many companies do not want contractors or even offshore subsidiaries. To become a solid SQA professional, it is necessary not just to know the essentials aspects of software dev and delivery, but also to stay current about the emerging trends and tools, which requires a “continuous learning” attitude. Software testers also need to be professional and fact-based in their communications while staying aware of the market pressures and customer demands. Good luck,

Of course, it is.  It’s true that people think that developers are the rulers of the tech industry. They make the mobile apps a favorite addition to users’ lives. But, the reality is that it’s a ‘Bug-free and Efficient’ application that gain limelight in the mobile industry - something that comes under the job of testers (also called Quality analysts). BONUS: Quality Assurance Process – All about The Secret Weapon that can make or break your Mobile App It’s quality analysts who try and test every feature and functionality of a mobile application and ensure that it matches with the level of expectation of users. And hence, increase the chances of gaining visibility and higher revenue in the marketplace. In short, it’s a software tester which makes a mobile application capable of getting the attention of users and help businesses to make the best of the opportunity. And now, when there are more than 4 billion of mobile applications in the world and many more are planning to enter the market, it has become even more important to test your application efficiently and effectively. Meaning, the job opportunities for software testers are increasing. So, it is a good decision to hone your analyzing skills, learn about the best mobile app testing strategies and enter into the world of software testing. Still not convinced? Drop a comment below and I will provide you assistance in understanding the dynamics of Testing and making a better choice.

Hi, Well as per my opinion, no occupation is good or bad and it depends upon interests and capabilities. If you are looking to change to your career into software testing field, its better if you evaluate yourself in terms of your interests, passion and capabilities. I have seen people who really does not like coding or feel difficult to write code often looks to pursue their career in software testing field, however later on its become difficult to sustain and grow to upper level positions. Software testing is also a very challenging field where one need to keep himself updated on new areas of testing, tools, technologies, continuously work on their project management and leadership skills. Clients are now demanding for people who can perform every type of testing like Functional, Automation, API,etc One should have ability to understand the new requirements or features, identify the missing features and participate actively and closely with development and product management team to provide his feedback. You should have good logical thinking, communication and interpersonal skills to grow in this field. You should also ready to learn new skills based on changing requirements. So as verdict if you have interest in testing the software, thinking out of box to identify missing requirements and bugs, good communication skills, then I will definitely advise you to move into this field. Skills can be learned and improved over a period of time, but at same time you should have passion and motivation to work in this field. There are many top software testing companies where you can opt to pursue and work in this field. Hope this will make you better understanding before you plan to make career into field. Let me know if any further information is needed. Regards, Anand

Absolutely, Software testing is the best career choice and all it depends on how you take it. It has a reputation to be a job where people unexpectedly fall in and after some time, starts liking it. In the past few years, Software Testing has become an extremely good career choice in terms of professional growth, learning experience, and income. The testing domain is growing in the industry and with the new age of automation and companies experimenting towards Agile Methodology, DevOps, and IoT. The demand for a software tester is greater without enough number of skilled candidates. Besides, you should learn development for doing test automation it is much required for writing the test framework. To survive as a software tester, you need to learn selenium, coding, scripting, have good documentation skills, and learn other front end and middle tier technologies. You may also do a small project every time while you learn. Well. with the growth in the advancement of technology, the scope of software testing is growing rapidly. Both that is in the field of Job career or in the field of development or deployment. As a software tester, you are included in the quality assurance stage of software development and deployment. Although, assessing code is one part of the role of a software tester. Once you come to the field you will automatically come to understand what are the challenges and what is the scope for being a software tester.

Tell me what job is not a good career? Anything that you do with love for it and enjoy while doing it could be a good job. And career is all about how build it. And if you are thinking about money you could earn, it is all about selling your expertise! Try To be an expert at something you do, and the better you sell it the better you earn!  I could say good or bad is very relative. While something is good for one it might be bad for another. Now the point is to check if it is good for you or not!! To decide this probably you have to assess yourself, assess the job opportunity, and then map both of them. Check if this is what you're looking at! When speaking about software testing, see if you are guy with good perseverance, question skills, able to think out of the box at every context, able to assess some product and could derive your opinions on how you can make it better - then it is a good option for you. You can do wonders I say! All the best!

Software Testing: Software Testing is a process of verifying a computer system/program to decide whether it meets the specified requirements and produces the desired results. Software testing also helps to identify errors, gaps or missing requirements in contrary to the actual requirements. As a result, you identify bugs in software product/project. It helps to provide stakeholders with information about the quality of the software product or service under test. It ensures that the software system is a Defect free. Software Testing - a good career choice: Yes, off-course Software Testing is a good career choice. Specially if your Academic background is Computer Science. If you hold degrees like BTech/ B.E., MCA, BCA, BSc- Computers, will land you a job quickly. But if you do not hold any of these degrees, then you must complete a software testing certification like ISTQB and CSTE which help you learn Software Development/ Test Life Cycle and other testing methodologies. If you love - to solve logical puzzlesto help othersto take challengesto write codeto interact with peopleto be in a team where quality products are delivered,it can surely become the good career choice. Some Practical reasons why Software Testing is a Good Career Option: S/W Testing is in DemandTesters get Good PayRelatively easy to enter into IT through S/W TestingSwitch from Development to Testing is EasyTesting tools are easy to learnKind of 9 to 6 jobGood Onsite OpportunitiesCan work as FreelancerRelatively easy to come back after the career gapCareer Shift from Testing to BA is easySoftware Tester Career Path: Your career progression as a software tester, you can become: QA Analyst (Fresher)Sr. QA Analyst (2-3 years' experience)QA Team Coordinator (5-6 years' experience)Test Manager (8-11 years' experience)Senior Test Manager (14+ experience)

Absolutely. Testers are an essential part of the software team. I've known developers who became testers and were happier because they didn't have to clean up the mess when things didn't work, they just had to report that they were broken. Kinda like just giving your car over to a mechanic with little more than “the lights don't work” and being done with it. So if you have the temperament for the position and it is something that interests you, then by all means consider pursuing testing. It's a profession that is always in demand, thus opportunity will be there for you.

I think software testing is an excellent career! I have been in Software testing/technology for 7+ years now and this is by far the most lucrative and wonderful career. First of all, for most testing jobs, you do not need to know any coding/languages. Second, it is not taught in schools so it is a very unique skill to have and there is a always a demand for it. Third and by far the best thing about software testing is that it pays extremely well. You can basically make from 70k to 100k + without knowing any code. Anyone can do this. If you are interested, I have made a course online on how to get a job in technology as a software tester without any experience. Software testing is one of those career areas that you know isn’t going away any time soon. Sure—testing automation is becoming increasingly popular, but that’s not one of the cases where automation takes jobs away; if anything—it creates more jobs for QA engineers and software testers. Many times, we feel a sense of disappointment if the first assignment in our first job is a testing project. This is because the curriculum of software engineering does not include the software testing discipline. So we are unprepared to perceive that topics other than development, DB or network have anything to contribute to software production. It is natural to feel slightly cheated. Besides all of this, Career in testing nowadays is getting very popular as more and more new technologies are coming to town. So press the pedal on the accelerator and boost up your speed . I myself works in a testing firm—LambdaTest and I can easily see the rapid growth of this company.

I love the works of Tim Ferriss and his practical approach to problems. When someone asks Tim if they should become a writer, he always says ’No’. The reason for this is that if you really need to be asking someone else, odds are that it’s not among your biggest desires or passions. I work in testing and for me it was always a no-brainer to become a tester. I love exploring and curiosity and new technologies so much. I see myself as an early adopter and for me testing is at the forefront of all up and coming technologies and software products. So my advice for a career choice would be simple. If you can answer your own question with a ”Hell yeah!” -kind of answer, then it is a good career choice. If you feel like you don’t know about it enough yet, then dive in and then make up your mind after tasting.

According to Wikipedia, Software testing is an investigation conducted to provide stakeholders with information about the quality of the product or service under test. Software testing can also provide an objective, independent view of the software to allow the business to appreciate and understand the risks of software implementation. Test techniques include the process of executing a program or application with the intent of finding software bugs (errors or other defects), and verifying that the software product is fit for use. Are you kidding me? Software Testing is the best career you can choose. It's a dream career. Hell, if I would have know 8 years ago, I would have chosen testing over development :( My peers, the under performers who were given testing (the good performers were put to development) have since then  1. Spent anywhere between 6 months to 6 years onsite; we didn't go anywhere for even a week2. Earned lakhs of rupees as salaries and onsite money, built bank balances and purchased houses and properties and cars; we just earned our basic salaries3. Few stayed onsite, changed companies and settled there; some even married there. We just dreamt.  Everyone is still doing good. What else would you want from life! Go for it, but be the best at it :)

Yes, software testing is a good career choice. SOFTWARE TESTING is defined as an activity to check whether the actual results match the expected results and to ensure that the software system is Defect free. It involves the execution of a software component or system component to evaluate one or more properties of interest. Software testing also helps to identify errors, gaps, or missing requirements in contrary to the actual requirements. It can be either done manually or using automated tools. Some prefer saying Software testing as a White Box and Black Box Testing. If you really want to build your career in the software testing field. You should contact to software testing Edu. Software Testing Edu is the best testing institute located in Indore. Here, they provide complete software testing training. They provide Manual & Automation testing. They have the best faculty who have many years of experience.

If you are a perfectionist, you are going to love software testing! :) I wouldn't say that this is the best option to start your career with - the other fields like Software Development or SAP are equally good. However, the difference is the attitude and aptitude that you have for a particular job :) Testing will introduce you to a all round development around Communication skills, technical skills (tools, languages), industry processes and domain knowledge. The exposure is vast! However, you need very peculiar qualities (and that too in abundance) - patience and attention to details. I will not make this answer any longer and redirect to a fantastic description of 'what it is like to be a software tester'. Go to the following link and refer to the very well written summary by 'Vikrant Payal': Should I move to testing from software development? Good luck and may you choose the right fit :)

If you are good in observing & can think as a decoder, then Software Testing is really a good scope to excel in career. Moreover, Software Testing has many dimensions as in different types testing & multiple tools to enhance quality of the product or application.Apart from Functional Testing; Performance & Security Testing are also important aspect which you can aim to excel in. Just as an advice, do not restrict yourself to only Manual efforts as quality in less time & cost effective - is always preferred. Automation is the future if you are into Testing domain. With basic coding knowledge you can write your own scripts and automate the test cases. Core Java, Shell scripting, VB scripting are most commonly used to write automation code among test engineers.Apart from costly automation tool (like, HP QTP..) companies are inclining towards open-source tools (Selenium is most favourite) which are scalable and comes with zero cost. So trive to get the good hands on the automation tools after you get the good exposure & experience in Software Testing. Best Of Luck !! Hope this helps. For any further clarification, you can revert with your query. Thanks!

Software testing offers you opportunity to fully utilize your critical thinking and creativity to discover or see things that others do not see. It can be interesting, and intellectually challenging. You have to think out of the box- think of things and situations that others have overlooked. If those elusive bugs were easy to find, they probably wouldn't be there. It is less technological focused than software development, but it does not mean inferiority.  To begin with, there are a few experts like Lanette Creamer,Keith Klain,Pradeep Soundararajan,Matt Heusser who are experts in this field and you can read books published by them to get better understanding on this field.  Some of the testing skills you require as a tester would be understaning of the Project life cycle,Testing concepts,Knowledge of testing types,Programming languages familiarity,Database concepts,Test plan idea,Ability to analyze requirements,Documentation skill and familiarity with the Testing tools. You will most likely have parts of your job you could do without but finding something you have a passion for makes all the difference in the world. If you don't have a passion for software testing, you are likely better off finding something you are passionate about and pursuing a career in that field.

Of course it is. But that depends from you. Some people work in a store as clerk all their life; if it pay the bills and they are happy with that; then that is a good career choice. Some people have deep problems in accepting what is their place in society; and the only thing they see is to become a CEO. Nothing wrong with that, you need to dream big to go forward, but that makes you live your life always unsatisfied, because you (often incorrectly) think that you are wasting time in a career path. Any job is a good career choice, as long as it pays the bills, allow you go do most of what you want, and make you feel happy. If you can’t achieve this; then the problem is not the career choice but you.

Yes, it is! Software testing is a flexible career. You don’t necessarily need to be committed to a daily desk job if you are a tester. You can work while you are on the go, in the comfort of your home. Software testing also offers a secure career path too. Though it is ever dynamic and constantly seeing the rise of new technologies, having methods changed from being manual to automated, and testing platforms have gone from computers to mobile devices, but it is still in demand. Software testing also opens doors to a lot more other amazing career avenues for you. With a good understanding and experience in manual testing, you can explore your potential further and become a business analyst, performance tester, or even an automation tester. So go for it if you love it, it is a good career path.

Definitely it is the best career choice and all it depends on how you take it. You should also learn development for doing test automation it is much needed for writing test framework. Your question is very generic so as the answer, if you explore more on your question then I have lot more to say. If your question is like, I am choosing software testing as my career option what should I learn? Then answer to this is as below. Learn coding, scripting, have good documentation skills, learn selenium and other front end and middle tier technologies, do a small project each time while you learn, after a year or so you are in good position to do lot more then software testing. Look at my github profile you will see my learnings: https://www.github.com/jageepjain  HTH.

It basically depends on you, it does need a lot of effort like other tech jobs, depends whether you fit into testing applications rather than developing, you will still be programming if you are an automation tester. However, at times the area of testing is given low importance than development, but basically that depends on the organisational management of the place where you are working at. Usually testers tend to eventually make their way up to Managerial roles in a few years e.g. QA Managers etc. So as i started it depends on the individual whether the roles and responsibilities of a QAE are something they are interested in or not.

Hello, Absolutely! Software testing is an excellent career choice for the simple reason that software development is constantly growing and for every software made, you need testers to confirm its quality and functionality. It is a thriving industry and provides the following benefits: Good payHuge demand for testersExciting workGood learning curveScope for immense growthAll the above perks will be irrelevant if you are not someone who loves codes, programming languages, new technologies and IT in general. To find out if software testing is a suitable career for you, attend a career counselling session with a brand like VedAtma. They follow a comprehensive process to help you become your best in the field you choose after careful analysis. Hope this helps! Disclaimer: I am an Educational Consultant at VedAtma. We provide assistance in making educational and career choices best aligned to your unique natural potential. If you have any further questions, you can contact us at- 0484 - 2308025, +91 - 8330848025

If you are Fresh graduate from university and thinking about which career to choose? Software Development or Testing / QA? Is Software Testing a good career choice? Does Testing has future? Do Testers get decent Salary? Then let me assure you that Software Testing/ QA is a good career option. I am an IT Engineer by qualification and a Software Test Engineer /QA by profession. Being into IT and Software Testing for more than 10 years, I have never regretted my decision to take Software Testing as my career. Below are 10 practical reasons why Software Testing/QA is a good career option 10 Practical Reasons Why Software Testing / QA is a Good Career Option - opencodez

If you are a fresher and want to be an IT professional, software testing would give a kick start to your career. In past few years, Software Testing has become an extremely good career choice in terms of professional growth, learning experience and income. If you want to grow more in this field you can go further with becoming a Developer later.

No, absolutely not. Rather you should focus on becoming a Developer. If you are not able to become anything else, then you must think about becoming a Software Tester. But if you decide to become a Software Testing Professional at the beginning of your Career then I would suggest you try Stool Testing first. There is absolutely no difference between a Software or an Application prepared by Developers and a sample of Stool. Both are *hit. So, testing the former should prepare you for the hard life of a Software Tester. All the best. May the “Bug” be with you.

Software testing is a career which would never go out of demand. In today’s tech world, millions of software’s are developed every day and at the same speed the rate of hackers is increasing. So, it is very important that the developer keeps his users safe from such hacker and also from bugs. Software testers are in demand, the capability of the software has to be tested before making it available for billions of people. It is must that the users should not face any difficulties or see any errors while using that software and to come over that the beta/alpha or pre-release variants of the software have to be tested by a software tester/ pen tester.

Most definitely you can have a rewarding career in software testing. I've been a software tester (among playing other roles in software development) for over 15 years. I think a good place to start is in support. Understanding how the customer/client uses the software is very important to developing good tests. Get a certification. I am a Certified Software Test Engineer through QAI. The training is very helpful in understanding software quality assurance standards and methodologies. It will also help you understand the SDLC.

IMHO. A career in software testing is definitely a good choice. But, it comes with its own caveats, and they are: (1) Be completely proficient in at least one programming language- C, C++ (2) Learn scripting in Python. (3) Learn the fundamentals of OS and how automation tools work. Learn at least one open-source and one licensed tool. (4) Data Driven Testing; Setting up Test Data. If you are intent on pursuing a career in load testing learn a good and robust load testing tool. You need to be very proficient in understanding Data Structures in Computer Science, manual testing and automation testing. The load associated with manual testing is generally reduced viz an automation test tool, and testing can indeed be an interesting and lucrative career choice provided one knows the ropes. A good functional tester, if he wishes to, can later graduate to becoming a good business analyst or manager.

Understand what software testing means first? Similarly understand what software development means? What are different paths they may lead in the future and is that position you wanna see yourself in few years. Do rational thinking, don’t judge book by its cover. Success depends on what you want to see yourself doing every passing days, months and years. Take a day or two and make arrangements for your life according to your likings, findings and stick to it so that you donot regret in the future. Mind you that it will be yours and only yours decision and don’t blame others.

The demand for software testing professionals is increasing day by day as the technology is getting more and more advanced. The world is becoming digital in every sense. For an average human being, each of his day starts with a software or an app. So the future opportunities for a software tester is unquestionable. There is a very common notion that software testing jobs are less paid than the others. Thing is, most of the leading companies are paying software testers as much as software developers. This career is good for career growth. If you are interested in software testing, enroll into the software testing courses in Calicut which provides you live project training and 100$ placement assistance. Thank you !

Hi Anjinkya, Happy Diwali! Often students and employees ask me this question whether they will have a good career in Software Testing or Not? Here’s my reply to all the students: “The moment you stop improving and learning new skill sets and technologies, you will end up having worst career life!” These days a lot of expectations are there from QA they should know Selenium, Cypress, Java, JavaScript, Shell Script, Jenkins, Docker etc etc If you have good control of your knowledge and skillset then software Testing (Automation Testing) will be the BEST career choice for students, professionals and any individual who want to pursue a career in IT! Regards, Jatin Sharma  New Batch of Automation Testing and DevOps starts from 25th November 2019

Most definitely you can have a rewarding career in Software Testing. Getting a ISTQB Certification  and a training from Good Training Institute is very helpful in understanding software quality assurance standards and methodologies. It will also help you understand the SDLC.As per my knowledge SQUAD Infotech Pvt. Ltd. ( SQUAD INFOTECH PVT. LTD. ) is First and Dedicated Professional Software Testing Training Institute In Mumbai .A good software tester must have a good verbal and written communication skill.  Testing artifacts (like test cases/plans, test strategies, bug reports  etc) created by the software tester should be easy to read and  comprehend. Dealing with developers (in case of bugs or any other issue) will require a shade of discreetness and diplomacy. Academic background of a software tester should be in Computer Science. A  BTech/ B.E. , MCA , BCA , BSc- Computers will land you a job easily. you can see career options @ SMART HUNT 4 U

If you like testing or test automation, it is. As long as companies are writing software, testing is a skillset that will be in demand. If you can program in a business environment, even better. You can be an SDET, and have the best of both worlds. I've been doing it for 18 years, and haven't regretted it.

Depends on your ability, your available capital and alternative job offers. It is better then minimum wages jobs, but not as rewarding (both financially and Intellectually) as programming. Most people attempt to use such jobs to enter the software industry and then try to switch to programming or tech support. Your milleage will vary.

Yes, software testing is good for making career. But IT is a field where you need to learn new things time to time. To start career in testing you should know the manual testing. But I suggest you start your career in Manual+Automation not just in manual as after 2–3 years when you are going to switch your current job then there will be lot of opportunities for you if you have experience in automation. If you start with manual testing then there will be very less opportunities as every company nowadays demanding automation testers and after 2–3 years from now I suppose it will be mandatory for all to have experience in Automation.

No matter whether jobs are increasing or not. You need only one job which you are looking for. If we talk about Testing jobs, I am sure you will have to struggle in industry, unless you have very good connections with IT guys working at top managment. Once you get break, then you will be a routine IT engineer, no one differentiate between support people, developer and test engineer. All are same in managements eye.

Absolutely not, if you want to be a programmer further on. Of course, if you are desperate (like I was, back in Russia, at 46, when I took a QA job in California), then anything would do. But otherwise, try to stay away from this kind of job as far as possible. It’s a dead end.

It depends on the domain you are working for. I am also a tester in networking domain. Here, the networking domain knowledge is very important and the testing engineer contributes to the requirement specification of the product also. If you have good scope, you can be in testing. Moreover, you will be promoted easily if you are in testing, as many people choose development.

IF you reference to the Automation Testing, then a big YES. But, for manual testing, I am little bit skeptical to think about. Because, manual testers are also moving towards an automation domain. Hence, they could do both:- manual and automation. Furthermore, Automation Engineers are thinking out of box for every kind of automation whether it is voice integrated software like ALEXA, mobile apps, or web browser. There are lots of frameworks available to code for the above mentioned areas.

Yes. If you're passionate and skilled, you can be very well compensated.  I've seen remote QA gigs that pay $120k+ USD for Ruby on Rails testers that can use capybara and rspec.  I also think QA is much more fun than strait up development.  It's a personal choice.  Hope this helps.

Most companies have their QC departments, so it surely is a good career as of now. Future may be shaky for the career Ptah though. With automation and more open source and web review based economy, software testing might get distributed to other departments, although Quality Check will mostly exist even after software testing is gone. Suggest you to look for analytical or quality related options, and not just software testing.

Yes. All the customer will be satisfied If the product is tested effectively and efficiently.Now the testing is becoming automation slowly. The tester will get on-site opportunities compare than the developer. Design problems can be easily identified by the effective testing. Lot of certified courses available for testing. That will help to improve your career.

If you think a career is a boat that if you just sit on it, the winds will take the boat to heaven then any career is as good as another one. You can have any starting point and it is up to you on how you adjust the mast to go against the winds to the destination you want to reach to.

I would say it is, you will have the full picture of the application or the product. If you have doubt in your mind or slight hesitation then don’t opt for it as you will regret because you might not enjoy what you do. Software testing is not just finding some issue and that is it. It is also how to make sure that it doesn’t occur again and also you are not only doing manual testing anymore. The gap between the test engineers and the developers are shrinking as test engineers are supposed to get involved in every phase, especially in Agile environment.

Each career path is unique, we cannot deny it. To handover quality software products, you need software testing at development, release, and acceptance levels. In the information technology era, software development, cloud computing, and business management for mobile devices will remain high in demand for many years to come. If you want to become a software tester then I will suggest you join Software Testing Edu. There the faculty have a great experience and deep understanding of software testing skills. And they give wings to your dreams.

In past few years, Software Testing has become an extremely good career choice in terms of professional growth, learning experience and income. ... Although the main three preferable backgrounds are Domain Experts, Software Engineer/Computer Professional and Tester (testing runs in their blood).

Yes, obviously, Software Testing is a good career choice, if you have good analytical skills then it could be consider as a good option. Also if you are not very good at programming you can achieve best career goals in IT. Refer courses posted by "Narayanan Palani" on topic "ISTQB Advanced Level Test Automation Engineering Training" on "udemy" website.
Yes, of course, it's a good choice and has a lot of scope of as well if you are more interested in automation.

yes, software testing is a good career choice, here are so many options available for a software product or software services, BUT what matters is Quality. And when there is the talk of Quality, Testing / Quality Assurance comes into the picture. So, software testing is very much in demand and if you know Automation, then you are the company’s favourite.

Testing will definitely help you in case if you add some special skills with it. Ordinary Manual tester doesn’t attracts the market and IT companies these days. Either they are interested in acquiring testers with coding skills or someone with special skills. Try to develop expertise in automation testing and ETL. But sadly specialization is what industry demands when it comes to Quality Testing because now a days no one accepts manual testing; it needs to be coupled with something additional.

Yes software testing has a good career choice.A software tester has unique growth. It's a myth that there are no or little growth opportunities in software testing career.You should not stick to only manual testing but also go ahead with learning automation testing

It's a good choice for somebody who is detail oriented and willing to methodically go through a number of variations and log the details of any anomalies they find.  For such a person, this is a wonderful job. Other people will find that it's not a good fit for them.

It’s very promising, as our society gets more and more digital, there are many software products getting developed and they need to be tested / verified. The complexity of existing solutions also increses over time, making the work more challenging and rewarding. It’s important to keep an eye on market trends and automation though. There are tools like this that help automating quickly and control testing process on higher levels of abstraction.

Software testing is Very important because of some reason like. Detects and error that were made during the development phase. If you want build your career in IT then software testing is best career Choice. still if you have some doubt then visit some Institute in pune ther lots Institute take software testing training program with live project. Also some Institute like seed infotech, CRBtech , and Exceltech they provide job oriented training program for software testing.

I think I answered this question: Do test engineers easily become bored at their jobs? Also look at this answer: Is software testing job good for a computer science student? is there any scope in this field? But the real question is: what makes you feel good working on?
response.upvotes: Answer requested by Arun Kumar Nalla

response.answer_text: Yes, Software Testing is a good choice for a career. Many options are available in software testing profile.
As a software consultant, solution architect, product manager, software developer, all of those jobs will require testing as part of the job. I’ve never known of a “software testing” only position.

No. Software Testing is not stable career option. Development is stable. If you are good at development, you can go forth and come back between Dev, QA, Support. Now a days Testers are expected to program like Developers, but most of them do not have programming experience. Developer turned tester is the future. CODE-CODE-CODE…

Yes,Why not.There is great opportunity in software testing in india and foreign country also. Software testing have Automation testing and Manual testing. if you have manual and as well as Automation skills(Tools) like Selenium and ETL and others tools then you have greater oppertunnity in that Software testing carrier.

Yes ofcourse software testing has its future.You can choose your career in software testing.you better choose automation testing as your career. If you require any information about automation testing you can check tutorials at@http://www.softwaretesting-certification.com/
Go a head , it is very bright and long career. Try to learn automation testing. Automation testing will be remain in the market in future with high demand.

Yes of course, start with Manual Testing, creating test scenarios, understanding requirements and map the same with the test cases. Enhance your career with Test Automation. There are couple of software testing tools, start using the free available tools. Design your own framework and start exploring

It depends on your interest and skill. Basically interest and doing better in any field you can reach at the top. My thinking and observation is, automated testing career is growing. As a tester basic and Manual testing knowledge is a must.
Yes it it,, why you think so its not.. Every thing involve in the SDLC cycle is good.Testing make the product deliverable.
If you have the aptitude and the discipline to rigorously test software, then YES. Otherwise, you’ll have to go through the company ladder and learn at the feet of the masters.
You mean career choice. Yes it is. Please see similar questions on the same topic in quora. There are plenty of questions asked about testing which tells you a story!
Yes... Please choose this only if you are passionate about testing. later on, there are various automation opportunities are there where you can get a better salary structure.
Choose Automation testing you can grow more on big companies manual its preety old method but that too have a good scope on companies which they follows manual testing for projets

Developers or testers they both will come under software engineer designation. Testing have very good scope in future as soon as you started your career in testing, start learn about automation testing aswell.

*Tip# Manual Testing is NOT dead. But Manual Testers are* Believe it or not. Industry is searching for Software Testers who can test manually and then automate as well. Individual manual test roles are diminishing at a rapid pace. What you can do about it? Upskill. Upgrade!
Believe me, you won't find a better job than a QA Analyst in IT field. Its the best of IT without being core IT.
Yes MA.. It is
No.
